awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Extended Particles in Turbulent Flow: A Grand Computational Challenge
awd_abstract_narration:
1258398
PI: Prosperetti

This project is concerned with the development of a flexible and accurate numerical method, named Physalis, for the simulation of particulate flows. The work to date has shown that this method has significant advantages over the other methods used at present such as the lattice-Boltzmann method and the immersed-boundary methods in that the method permits the exact satisfaction of the no-slip condition on each particle and that each particle is represented in a spectrally convergent   fashion.  This permits simulations involving 1000 particles with sufficiently high accuracy for particle Reynolds numbers up to about 100. The objective of the work proposed here is to port the existing code to GPU-based computers with the goal of attaining speed up of at least two orders of magnitude.  The project will explore novel approaches to the parallelization of the code and memory management to achieve this speed up. The code thus developed will be made available to the research community through the PIs web.

Natural processes and contemporary technology offer a wealth of instances in which solid particles are transported by fluid flows: marine sediments, gravity currents, fluidized bed combustors, catalytic oil cracking and chemical looping combustors are just a few examples among many. A reliable theoretical understanding of these systems is essential for a variety of reasons ranging from the modeling of environmental flows to carbon sequestration, to the development of new or scaled-up designs without expensive preliminary experimentation and many others. Sophisticated numerical methods and state-of-the-art computational hardware to be employed in this project will be useful in advancing the understanding of particulate systems.

por.por_cntn:
In earlier NSF-sponsored work we had developed a computational method to simulate fluid flows containing many suspended particles. The motivation is the need to develop a better understanding of such flows which are encountered in nature (sand storms, sediment transport, avalanches and others) and in technology (fluidized beds in the oil and chemical industry, the food industry and others). While powerful and accurate, the code implementing the numerical method was very complex and executed slowly, thus hampering efforts to run a large number of simulations to better understand the dynamics of these complicated flows.The objective of the work supported by this grant was the re-writing of the code to make it usable on the new computers based on Graphic Processing Units (GPU's) with intent of increasing the execution speed. We were hoping for a 100-fold speed-up, but we actually achieved a 150-fold speed-up. This means that what required 24 hours with the old code, now takes only 9.6 minutes. It is now possible therefore to carry out a large number of simulations in a relatively short time (a few days as opposed to months). 

So far we have tested the code with up to 200 particles and are currently working to extend its capabilities to thousands of particles. At this point, this extension is a fairly minor undertaking and we are confident that it will be operational very soon. 

An example of the computed flow past a stationary bed of 200 particles with periodic boundary conditions in all directions is shown in one of the attached figures. The single-particle Reynolds number is around 30 and the particle volume fraction 20.4%. The other images show the sedimentation of 100 particles in a square duct with periodicity boundary conditions in the vertical direction and the shearing of a particle-fluid layer with 50 particles. The volume fractions in these two cases are 10.2% and the maximum single-particle Reynolds numbers about 60 and 16, respectively.
